awd_abstract_narration:
The GLOBE Youth Geoscientists (GYG) project will produce an innovative model for informal STEM education that can support transitions for diverse underserved high school students to postsecondary education and careers in the geosciences. It will provide hands-on, project-based science experiences using scientist-developed data collection protocols from the GLOBE program — Global Learning and Observations to Benefit the Environment — to engage youth as young professionals contributing to scientific knowledge. These experiences will be coupled with interactions with adult STEM professionals, career exploration, college preparation, and self-reflection activities, all within a safe and supportive setting. The program will help close a critical gap for students to obtain a real geosciences experience as a means to build competence, confidence, motivation, and belonging in the sciences. In addition, college exploration and preparatory activities will support students at a critical and vulnerable transition point in their education — bridging from high school to college — by providing college and career navigation skills, tours to college campuses, opportunities to interact with college students, and links to organizations that can assist with college and financial aid applications. The aim is to support as well as inspire. The partnership will facilitate engagement with scientists, industry professionals, and colleges, and will connect with the students’ school-year teachers by supporting senior projects and college application processes that build on the students’ summer experiences.

WestEd, together with its partners, the Lawrence Hall of Science (the Hall) and the College and Career Academy Support Network (CCASN), both at the University of California, Berkeley, will implement this project. The program will combine Global Learning and Observations to Benefit the Environment (GLOBE), career development experiences, college preparation, and youth development/leadership strategies to build a replicable summer geosciences experience for rising seniors in the East Bay region of the San Francisco Bay Area in California who are traditionally underrepresented in STEM careers and who might otherwise not receive important support at this critical juncture in their educational careers. GYG leverages GLOBE’s student driven approach to science to expand past work into an informal summer learning setting. It will also create an explicit college preparation component, consistent with the goals of the IUSE: GEOPATHS initiative. The GYG program will take an ecosystem approach to supporting youth, engaging scientists and STEM professionals as critical participants in the ecosystem. The goals of the project are as follows: 1) Create a GLOBE-infused learning-rich geoscience research experience for local students from populations underrepresented in the sciences to support their college entry and career readiness. 2) Expand the close collaboration between WestEd and CCASN to include the Lawrence Hall of Science and build capacity at the Hall to sustain GLOBE-infused programming beyond this grant. 3) Provide a model for a learning-rich geoscience experience for underserved youth that can be replicated by other informal learning organizations, in support of their local schools, offering summer learning and postsecondary preparation as well as fulfilling the policy goals of schools that promote college and career readiness. The evaluation component will help document the model’s components and processes and contribute to the knowledge base about engagement of youth from populations underrepresented in STEM, STEM career development and college-going, industry engagement, and program features that contribute to positive student outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

The GLOBE Youth Geoscientists Internship Program: Preparing for the Future though an Immersive Science Experience 

Overview. The GLOBE Youth Geoscientists (GYG) program was a two-week summer internship experience for underserved youth in the San Francisco Bay Area. It was offered over two years, the first year in Berkeley, California at the UC Berkeley Botanical Gardens, and the second year, at Lake Merritt in Oakland, California. The project was managed as a partnership between WestEd and UC Berkeley (the Lawrence Hall of Science, the Department of Chemistry, and the College and Career Alliance and Support Network).  Approximately 25 students participated over the two years; most were students of color and female.

The program consisted of four primary components: hands-on science, college preparation, career development, and social-emotional learning. Hands-on science was delivered through the Global Learning and Observations to Benefit the Environment (GLOBE) program, a NASA-funded international science and education platform. GLOBE enables youth to collect data in their local environments using scientist-developed protocols, and to enter those data into the GLOBE database for use by youth and professional researchers. In GYG, youth developed research questions, collected and analyzed their own data, and presented their projects.

In addition to doing science, the youth also participated in workshops related to college preparation. In addition, they engaged with role models and other professionals who provided insights about their career paths. Finally, the program was delivered with an intentional focus on building trust and creating a warm and supportive experience for the youth.

Project Value. GYG demonstrated how science can be taught effectively through inquiry-based, hands-on experiences that are relevant and engaging for all youth, including those from underserved communities.  These features not only address content knowledge, but center equity and the social-emotional dimensions of learning, including students’ interests in their communities and in their future careers.  Key program features include caring adults; high expectations; role models who “look like” the youth; youth voice and youth-led research; meaningful engagement with community-based content; active, multi-sensory learning; and projects that teach key 21st century skills, such as collaboration, teamwork, time management, and presentation skills, in addition to rigorous science practices. 

Broader Impact. The program provides a model for other informal learning programs and partnerships. While GYG was implemented in an informal summer internship environment that allowed for an immersive experience, GLOBE itself, and the key features of the program, can also be implemented in formal settings and are highly useful in providing tools and resources to any educators who want to teach Earth science and inspire youth through motivating activities and project-based learning.

Key results. Key results include the following:

  • Students reported increased interests in pursuing a career in STEM, learning new subjects in school, and going into the field to collect data. Students especially reported that the program greatly increased their interest in how to research topics they are curious about, learning about the environment, and learning more about nature.     
  • Students reported that the program helped them develop knowledge and many skills.  Students reported that the program helped them “a lot” with developing the knowledge to do research (92%), using science to answer a question (85%), and working with others (85%). In addition, over three-quarters reported that the program helped them in listening to others’ points of view and identifying their own interests. 
  • Finally, nearly two-thirds of the students reported being much more interested in taking leadership in addressing a problem that they care about (62%) and working together with other people to solve problems (62%).
  • All students reported that they would recommend the program to a friend, saying that they enjoyed it, learned a lot, gained new friends, and that it was a great opportunity to learn and do science. They learned teamwork and became more confident.  Here are a few quotes from the students:

1.     It was overall an amazing experience. Great mentors and great peers. I love working hands on with science and it was my first time doing field work. GYG had a really positive impact on me and my passion.

2.     It is a fantastic opportunity to learn about both stem and the environment, if you are interested in science and the environment then it’s a great internship!

3.     I really enjoyed it, I learned a great deal and met lots of great people. I conducted scientific research like I’ve always wanted to, I’m glad I did it.

4.     It gave me a different point of view of science and research and genuinely made it more interesting.

5.     I loved it. I mean like I don't want to sound dramatic, but it was kind of like life changing....When I applied … I wanted to go into psychology .... [After] I changed my [class] schedule … to AP environmental science. I loved it so much and now environmental science is my major."
